title: David Hermann
text:
David Hermann (born 1977) is a German-French <a href="stage%20director">stage director</a> focused on <a href="opera">opera</a>. In 2006, Hermann was the youngest stage director at the <a href="Salzburg%20Festival">Salzburg Festival</a>, and he has directed operas at major opera houses in Europe. 
Career.
Born in <a href="W%C3%BCrzburg">Würzburg</a>, Hermann studied stage directing at the <a href="Hochschule%20f%C3%BCr%20Musik%20%26quot%3BHanns%20Eisler%26quot%3B">Hochschule für Musik "Hanns Eisler"</a> in Berlin. He worked as an assistant of <a href="Hans%20Neuenfels">Hans Neuenfels</a>. In 2000, he was awarded the first prize of the "Internationaler Wettbewerb für Regie und Bühnenbild" (International competition for direction and stage set) in <a href="Graz">Graz</a>. He staged a cycle of three <a href="Claudio%20Monteverdi">Monteverdi</a> operas at the <a href="Frankfurt%20Opera">Frankfurt Opera</a>.
Hermann made his debut at the <a href="Salzburg%20Festival">Salzburg Festival</a> with a production of Mozart's "<a href="Ascanio%20in%20Alba">Ascanio in Alba</a>" in 2006, then at age 29 as the youngest director at the festival. He directed Verdi's "<a href="Rigoletto">Rigoletto</a>" at the <a href="Deutsche%20Oper%20am%20Rhein">Deutsche Oper am Rhein</a> in 2009, and the same year at the festival <a href="Ruhrtriennale">Ruhrtriennale</a> the premiere of "Sing für mich, Tod! A ritual for Claude Vivier" by to music by <a href="Claude%20Vivier">Claude Vivier</a>. He directed Honegger's "<a href="Jeanne%20d%27Arc%20au%20b%C3%BBcher">Jeanne d'Arc au bûcher</a>" at the <a href="Theater%20Basel">Theater Basel</a>, and Verdi's "<a href="Macbeth%20%28opera%29">Macbeth</a>" at the <a href="Aalto%20Theatre">Aalto Theatre</a> in Essen. He staged at the <a href="Deutsche%20Oper%20Berlin">Deutsche Oper Berlin</a> first in 2012 <a href="Helmut%20Lachenmann">Helmut Lachenmann</a>'s "Das Mädchen mit den Schwefelhölzern" and then Janáček's "<a href="The%20Makropulos%20Affair%20%28opera%29">Věc Makropulos</a>". He directed for the <a href="Badisches%20Staatstheater%20Karlsruhe">Badisches Staatstheater Karlsruhe</a> "<a href="Les%20Troyens">Les Troyens</a>" by Berlioz, Mussorgsky's "<a href="Boris%20Godunov%20%28opera%29">Boris Godunov</a>", and in 2016 Wagner's "<a href="Das%20Rheingold">Das Rheingold</a>". He staged Dvořák's "<a href="Rusalka%20%28opera%29">Rusalka</a>" in Saarbrücken and Verdi's "<a href="La%20traviata">La traviata</a>" at the <a href="Zurich%20Opera">Zurich Opera</a>. In 2017, he staged three short operas by Ernst Krenek, connecting them to "Drei Opern" (Three operas) in a different order from the 1928 premiere at the <a href="Internationale%20Maifestspiele%20Wiesbaden">Mai-Woche Wiesbaden</a>: he showed after "<a href="Der%20Diktator">Der Diktator</a>" first "<a href="Schwergewicht">Schwergewicht, oder Die Ehre der Nation</a>", and then "<a href="Das%20geheime%20K%C3%B6nigreich">Das geheime Königreich</a>", interpreting the works as parables on power and its abuse. A reviewer noted the followed the music as a mix of tragedy, farce and fairy-tale about politics and culture ("... eine fabelhafte Mischung von Tragödie, Farce und Märchen über Politik und Kultur").
Hermann also worked in Europe for the <a href="De%20Nationale%20Opera">De Nationale Opera</a> in Amsterdam, the <a href="Vlaamse%20Opera">Vlaamse Opera</a> in Antwerp, the <a href="Op%C3%A9ra%20national%20de%20Lorraine">Opéra national de Lorraine</a> in Nancy, and the <a href="Teatro%20Real">Teatro Real</a> in Madrid.
